image.altText: A crowd of people stand on the street outside an Optus store

items.synopsis: Optus says it "may take a few hours for all services to recover", with the telco yet to identify the root issue behind today's huge outage. Follow live.

title.children: Optus announces some services are being restored, but warns it may take a few hours

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Optus has just posted a new update on its website. It says internet and phone services "are continuing to be restored". "Service will be automatically restored," the statement says. "Some customers may need to restart their device or turn airplane mode on then off." Here's the rest of the statement:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Services are continuing to be restored,' Optus says

children.content: Optus has just posted a new update on its website.
It says internet and phone services "are continuing to be restored".
"Service will be automatically restored," the statement says.
"Some customers may need to restart their device or turn airplane mode on then off."
Here's the rest of the statement:
(Supplied)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin has repeated her apologies for the outage but says the company cannot provide further detail about the outage until it conducts a thorough investigation. "In my three and a half years, as the CEO of Optus, we've never had an outage of this nature," she said. "So it's a very rare occurrence, but unfortunately, it does happen. It happens to telcos all around the world. It happens to other telcos in Australia. "We try and avoid it happening and we will make sure we learn as much as we possibly can from what occurred and hopefully keep it as an extremely rare occurrence." You can read more about what she said here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Optus CEO says the outage was 'a very rare occurrence'

featuredLink.title: Optus blames 'technical network fault' for outage but needs further investigation to determine root cause

children.content: Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin has repeated her apologies for the outage but says the company cannot provide further detail about the outage until it conducts a thorough investigation.
"In my three and a half years, as the CEO of Optus, we've never had an outage of this nature," she said.
"So it's a very rare occurrence, but unfortunately, it does happen. It happens to telcos all around the world. It happens to other telcos in Australia.
"We try and avoid it happening and we will make sure we learn as much as we possibly can from what occurred and hopefully keep it as an extremely rare occurrence."
You can read more about what she said here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin says the company's services have been restored after today's major network outage affected millions of Australians. In an interview with the ABC, she said the cause was a "technical network issue" and a "thorough, root-cause analysis" would be conducted by the company before more information could be provided. Ms Bayer Rosmarin said such an outage was a "very rare occurrence" that happens to telcos around the world, including to other telcos in Australia. When asked about possible compensation, she said the company had been focused on restoring services but "would now start thinking about ways in which we can thank customers for their patience... and rewarding them for their loyalty to Optus".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BREAKING: Optus says a 'technical network fault' was to blame

children.content: Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin
says the company's
services have been restored after today's major network outage affected millions of Australians.
In an interview with the ABC, she said the cause was a "technical network issue" and a "thorough, root-cause analysis" would be conducted by the company before more information could be provided.
Ms Bayer Rosmarin said such an outage was a "very rare occurrence" that happens to telcos around the world, including to other telcos in Australia.

When asked about possible compensation, she said the company had been focused on restoring services but "would now start thinking about ways in which we can thank customers for their patience... and rewarding them for their loyalty to Optus".

image.altText: A sandstone window with yellow "yes" writing and an Optus sign.

items.synopsis: Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin says "a technical network fault" is to blame for the company's nationwide outage on Wednesday, but can't provide more information on the cause before conducting a deeper analysis.

title.children: Optus blames 'technical network fault' for outage but needs further investigation to determine root cause

items.synopsis: A Perth woman who held the heads of both her young children underwater in an inflatable pool is jailed, and banned from ever contacting them again.

title.children: Perth woman jailed after holding children's heads underwater in blow-up pool

items.synopsis: Northern Territory cattle producer Colin Deveraux knows he is lucky to be alive after being attacked by a 3.2-metre saltwater crocodile.

title.children: 'He shook me like a rag doll': Cattleman survives croc attack by biting back

image.altText: Composite image of two young men, with police behind them.

items.synopsis: A man who lit bushfires and filmed videos pledging his loyalty to Islamic State is found guilty of terrorism-related offences, but his older brother will walk free after being cleared by a jury.

title.children: Man who pledged loyalty to IS and lit fires on Melbourne's outskirts is found guilty of terror offences

image.altText: The crumpled front of a white BMW SUV, surrounded by emergency services tape.

items.synopsis: Police have interviewed the driver at the centre of a tragic crash that killed five people in the regional Victorian town of Daylesford, but no charges have been laid.

image.altText: Palestinian family reacts following Israeli airstrike

items.synopsis: At least 500 more people, most of them foreign nationals, cross into Egypt after the Rafah border crossing re-opens, while an Israeli government spokesperson tells the ABC the country will have to exercise "ultimate security control" over the Gaza Strip. Follow live.

title.children: DFAT confirms three Australians among new Rafah crossing evacuations, Israel wants 'ultimate security control' over Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier today we reported that three more Australians have been evacuated from Gaza to Egypt via the Rafah crossing, bringing the total of evacuated Australians to 28. The evacuation of a family of three Australians took place overnight, Foreign Minister Penny Wong confirmed in a post on X. "An Australian family of three has been able to leave Gaza via the Rafah crossing overnight", Foreign Minister Penny Wong said. "They are being supported by our consular staff in Egypt." DFAT continues to assist 76 people remaining in Gaza, she said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian family of three evacuated from Gaza overnight, DFAT continues to assist 76 people, Wong says

children.content: Earlier today we reported that
three more Australians have been evacuated from Gaza
to Egypt via the Rafah crossing, bringing the total of evacuated Australians to 28.
The evacuation of a family of three Australians took place overnight, Foreign Minister Penny Wong confirmed in a post on X.
"An Australian family of three has been able to leave Gaza via the Rafah crossing overnight", Foreign Minister Penny Wong said.
"They are being supported by our consular staff in Egypt."
DFAT continues to assist 76 people remaining in Gaza, she said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: G7 foreign ministers discussed how to revitalise peace efforts in the Middle East and the "day after" in the Gaza Strip once the conflict there recedes as they met for a two-day summit in Tokyo. The subject was brought up during a working dinner late on Tuesday, host Japan said in a statement, with the group due to continue talks on Wednesday. The statement gave no details of options being discussed if the Hamas militant group is ousted from Gaza. Diplomats in Washington, the United Nations, the Middle East and beyond have also started weighing the options. Discussions include the deployment of a multinational force to post-conflict Gaza, an interim Palestinian-led administration that would exclude Hamas politicians, a stopgap security and governance role for neighbouring Arab states and temporary UN supervision of the territory, Reuters reported. G7 foreign ministers are due to issue a statement mentioning the Israel-Gaza crisis later today, marking only the second such joint statement from the group on the issue since October 7. The statement will present the G7's "united stance" on the Middle East situation, Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Hirokazu Matsuno said. It is expected to include a call for humanitarian pauses, temporary breaks in fighting to allow aid into the besieged enclave, Japanese media reported on Wednesday. The G7 is made up of Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States, with the European Union also participating in the talks.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: World leaders including G7 begin discussions about the future of Gaza post-war

children.content: G7 foreign ministers

It is expected to include a call for humanitarian pauses, temporary breaks in fighting to allow aid into the besieged enclave, Japanese media reported on Wednesday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's military says it has located and destroyed more tunnels used by Hamas in northern Gaza, including one near an amusement park and another near a university. The IDF has published vision and a folder of photos appearing to show troops and bulldozers near Al Noor amusement park south of Gaza City. On Telegram, it said it located an underground tunnel running adjacent to the theme park and destroyed it. The folder of images also included a photo appearing to show soldiers and tanks in the vicinity of a different ferris wheel about 9 kilometres away. Map data analysed by the ABC indicates this ferris wheel is located near the Al Hilal (The Crescent) Sports Club, near the coast north of Gaza City. The IDF did not comment on what its soldiers were doing in this area in its Telegram post. In its update, it also said it had destroyed an "underground tunnel shaft and a weapons warehouse" containing chemicals and mines, found near a university, but the ABC could not identify the location from the provided vision. Earlier today the IDF said it was moving into the "heart of Gaza city". Both ferris wheels are located about 5km away from the city centre. The ABC could not independently verify when the IDF's photos were taken.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hamas tunnel near Gaza theme park destroyed, IDF says

children.content: Israel's military says it has located and destroyed more tunnels used by Hamas in northern Gaza, including one near an amusement park and another near a university.

The IDF has published vision and a folder of photos appearing to show troops and bulldozers near Al Noor amusement park south of Gaza City. On Telegram, it said it located an underground tunnel running adjacent to the theme park and destroyed it.

props.alt: A soldier standing in an arid area, with a ferris wheel in the distance

children.content: The IDF says it destroyed a tunnel shaft near the Al Noor amusement park.
(Supplied: IDF)

props.alt: A view of a ferris wheel from below with a tree in front

children.content: The ferris wheel near the Al Noor theme park, pictured in June 2021.

In its update, it also said it had destroyed an "underground tunnel shaft and a weapons warehouse" containing chemicals and mines, found near a university, but the ABC could not identify the location from the provided vision.
